page.title: 04SOUTH FARM - BUILDINGS
page.content: South Farm has been owned since the 1950s by Mr.Atkinson,whose family had been renting it since the turn of the century when they migrated to the area from the Lake District.The farm house is six hundred years old,long & low with two-storeys.Built of red brick, this has been altered and added to a number of times over the centuries. The working farm buildings include a small herringbone milking parlour for eight cows,whish is housed in an old converted stone barn.Other barns are used as machine sheds.There are a number of new larger barns,built of metal,which are used for storing crops and rearing calves.Near the house is an old square wooden granary, raised on staddle stones which is now disused.Also disused is a mill,built in the last century,the last,as well as the highest mill on the R.Meon.
